Description: Body sherd of thick-walled Clazomenian black-figured pottery vessel, probably a closed vessel; interior: broken away with remaining bit reserved; exterior: black-figure decoration consisting of siren to left (part of wing in added red with row of dots in added white and part of red and white alternating tail feathers remaining).
Curator's comments: Object owned and held by the Ashmolean Museum, Oxford. This record is included in the British Museum database as part of the Museum’s Naukratis Project, a research collaboration that aims to virtually re-unite finds from the ancient port city of Naukratis, now distributed over 80 museums worldwide.
Sirens are commonly depicted on vases from the Urla Group. Pencil 'f' on inside.
Bibliographic references: Cook 1952 / A List of Clazomenian Pottery (p. 139, no. 11) (labelled as 1912.33 (f))
Villing et al 2013-2015 / Naukratis: Greeks in Egypt (GH.064) (Phase 1)
Previous owner: Currently owned by: Ashmolean Museum, University of Oxford
